attributes.name: help
attributes.value: Features of an applied stimulus. This is useful when storing the raw stimulus is impractical

attributes.doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive information if the primary description field is populated with a computer-readable string.
attributes.name: comments

attributes.doc: Description of TimeSeries
attributes.name: description

attributes.doc: The base unit of measure used to store data. This should be in the SI unit. COMMENT: This is the SI unit (when appropriate) of the stored data, such as Volts. If the actual data is stored in millivolts, the field 'conversion' below describes how to convert the data to the specified SI unit.
attributes.name: unit

attributes.doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified unit
attributes.name: conversion

attributes.doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the specified by unit. COMMENT: E.g., the change in value of the least significant bit, or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use -1.0
attributes.name: resolution

datasets.doc: Values of each feature at each time.
datasets.name: data

datasets.doc: Units of each feature.
datasets.name: feature_units

datasets.doc: Description of the features represented in TimeSeries::data.
datasets.name: features

groups.doc: Abstract features, such as quantitative descriptions of sensory stimuli. The TimeSeries::data field is a 2D array, storing those features (e.g., for visual grating stimulus this might be orientation, spatial frequency and contrast). Null stimuli (eg, uniform gray) can be marked as being an independent feature (eg, 1.0 for gray, 0.0 for actual stimulus) or by storing NaNs for feature values, or through use of the TimeSeries::control fields. A set of features is considered to persist until the next set of features is defined. The final set of features stored should be the null set.

datasets.doc: Annotations made during an experiment.
datasets.name: data

groups.doc: Stores, eg, user annotations made during an experiment. The TimeSeries::data[] field stores a text array, and timestamps are stored for each annotation (ie, interval=1). This is largely an alias to a standard TimeSeries storing a text array but that is identifiable as storing annotations in a machine-readable way.

datasets.doc: >0 if interval started, <0 if interval ended.
datasets.name: data

groups.doc: Stores intervals of data. The timestamps field stores the beginning and end of intervals. The data field stores whether the interval just started (>0 value) or ended (<0 value). Different interval types can be represented in the same series by using multiple key values (eg, 1 for feature A, 2 for feature B, 3 for feature C, etc). The field data stores an 8-bit integer. This is largely an alias of a standard TimeSeries but that is identifiable as representing time intervals in a machine-readable way.
